item.title: Effects of local drug crisis evident in Kamsack, Sask.
item.description:
Effects of local drug crisis evident in Kamsack, Sask.

If the first step to recovery is admitting there's a problem, three First Nations around Kamsack, in east-central Saskatchewan, have reached that point. ​Leaders of the Federation of Saskatchewan Indian Nations and the Key, Cote and Keeseekoose First Nations sounded the alarm this week about a crisis in their communities.

item.title: Drug Dealers Explain How They Keep Their Hustles Secret from Their Families | VICE | United States
item.description:
Drug Dealers Explain How They Keep Their Hustles Secret from Their Families | VICE | United States

The are many reasons people deal drugs, but they are generally pretty simple. Some do it because they don't have any other way to survive. Some do it because it gives them power, or it gives them the trappings of status, wealth, and control that can result from the hustle.

item.title: The day police told Parliament to end the war on drugs
item.description:
The day police told Parliament to end the war on drugs

By Simon Oxenham Last week Neil Franklin, a retired major from Maryland State Police, led a troop of serving and former police chiefs, soldiers and a former spy into the Parliament to call MPs to end the war on drugs. Their testimony was damning and revealing.

item.title: The Nightmare Scenario: President Donald Trump Dictates US Drug Policy
item.description:
The Nightmare Scenario: President Donald Trump Dictates US Drug Policy

It looks increasingly as though Donald Trump will become the Republican candidate. And some reputable analysts then favor him to become president. It's enough to keep anyone awake at night. So what would a Trump presidency look like from the standpoint of drug policy? First, let's

item.title: Liberal Democrats become first major party to back cannabis legalisation
item.description:
Liberal Democrats become first major party to back cannabis legalisation

The Liberal Democrats have become the first major party to support the legalisation of cannabis, a move, they argue, that will reduce drug-related crime and raise around £1bn in tax revenue. The policy was overwhelmingly approved by delegates at the Lib Dems' spring conference in York on Saturday.

item.title: Leading California Anti-Pot Activist Says Marijuana Causes 'Almost All' Mass Murders
item.description:
Leading California Anti-Pot Activist Says Marijuana Causes 'Almost All' Mass Murders

Harry Anslinger, who directed the Federal Bureau of Narcotics from 1932 to 1962, famously described marijuana as a "killer weed" that inspired irrational acts of savage violence. Anslinger's method was simple: He would identify crimes committed by marijuana users and assert that the drug must have been the cause.

item.title: The Needle, the Cops, and How You Really 'Hit Bottom' | VICE | United States
item.description:
The Needle, the Cops, and How You Really 'Hit Bottom' | VICE | United States

The following is an excerpt from VICE drug columnist Maia Szalavitz's forthcoming book Unbroken Brain, published next month by St. Martin's Press. I opened the door with a needle in my arm. Seven plainclothes narcotics cops burst in, five burly men and two women, all shouting.

item.title: Why the British Empire Was Built on Rum
item.description:
Why the British Empire Was Built on Rum

For a long time, rum was a drink commonly issued to English sailors and soldiers. In the 18th century it replaced the traditional alcoholic beverages distributed to seamen and infantrymen, namely the more common beer and the less common wine and brandy.
